name: Turkmenian Pheasant
description: Similar in appearance to the nominate subspecies (common pheasant) but lacks a white collar. The male is colorful, with a brown body and dark pattern, a glossy metallic green head, and elongated tail feathers. The female is a subdued brown. Both have red facial wattles.
spread_note: Turkmenistan – a small area in the middle reaches of the Amu Darya River valleys
food_note: Invertebrates, seeds, underground plant parts, shoots
image_alt: Turkmenian pheasant, photo: Tomáš Adamec, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 42.5–53.5 cm; wing length 23.5–25.8 cm; weight 900–1,200 g
reproduction: Females lay 7–15 eggs in a ground depression and incubate them alone for 23–27 days.
attractions: Its lifestyle mirrors that of the common pheasant, introduced as a non-native species in some areas, including ours. The male is polygamous, attracting females during courtship with loud calls and a peculiar 'dance' involving wing-flapping and mock-pecking.
breeding: We have kept this subspecies since 2011, with the first two chicks hatching in 2012.
